column1: ap > 10:00|"after ten"|"‘Daddy
column4: and Alan has to get back to camp in time
column6: or something. All you really have to say is “long life and happiness to you both”.’"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 06:00|"Six o’clock"|"‘I say
column2: I’ll have to step on it. See you tomorrow

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"Ferrelyn watched the rear lights dwindle and vanish She stood listening until the erstwhile roar became a distant hum
column2: and then closed the front door. On her way back to the study she noticed that the hall clock now showed ten-fifteen."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"Ferrelyn watched the rear lights dwindle and vanish She stood listening until the erstwhile roar became a distant hum
column2: and then closed the front door. On her way back to the study she noticed that the hall clock now showed ten-fifteen.

column1: Still
column3: at ten-fifteen nothing in Midwich was abnormal.

column1: With the departure of Alan’s car peace was able to settle down again over a community which was
column3: engaged in winding up an uneventful day in expectation of a no less uneventful morrow."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"The last customers to be persuaded out of The Scythe and Stone had lingered for a few minutes to get their night-eyes and gone their ways
column2: and by ten-fifteen all but one Alfred Wait and a certain Harry Crankhart
column3: who were still engaged in argument about fertilizers
column4: had reached their homes."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"In the Vicarage
column3: Miss Polly Rushton was thinking that if only she had gone to bed half an hour ago she could be enjoying the book that now lay neglected on her knees
column4: and how much pleasanter that would be than listening to the present contest between her uncle and aunt. For
column5: on one side of the room Uncle Hubert
column7: was attempting to listen to a Third Programme disquisition on the Pre-Sophoclean Conception of the Oedipus Complex
column10: Aunt Dora was telephoning. Mr Leebody
column11: determined that scholarship should not be submerged by piffle
column12: had already made two advances in volume
column13: and still had forty-five degrees of knob turning in reserve. He could not be blamed for failing to guess that what was striking him as a particularly nugatory exchange of feminine concerns could turn out to be of importance. No one else would have guessed it

column1: ap 10:16|ten-sixteen|"The call was from South Kensington
column3: where a Mrs Cluey was seeking the support of her lifelong friend Mrs Leebody. By ten-sixteen she had reached the kernel of the matter."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 10:17|ten-seventeen|"‘Most inefficient
column2: ’ said Mrs Cluey. ‘I shall put in a written complaint. I refuse to pay for a minute more than we had – indeed
column3: I really don’t see why I should pay for that
column4: in the circumstances. We were cut off at ten-seventeen exactly.’"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: 22:17|"22.17 hrs"|"The man at the exchange responded with formal tact
column2: and made a note of the time
column3: for reference – 22.17 hrs 26th Sept.…"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: 22:17|"ten-seventeen that night"|"FROM ten-seventeen that night
column2: information about Midwich becomes episodic. Its telephones remained dead. The bus that should have passed through it failed to reach Stouch
column3: and a truck that went to look for the bus did not return. A notification from the R.A.F. was received in Trayne of some unidentified flying object
column7: detected by radar in the Midwich area
column8: possibly making a forced landing. Someone in Oppley reported a house on fire in Midwich
column11: nothing being done about it. The Trayne fire appliance turned out – and thereafter failed to make any reports. The Trayne police despatched a car to find out what had happened to the fire-engine
column14: vanished into silence. Oppley reported a second fire
column21: and sent off on his bicycle to Midwich; and no more was heard of him

column1: 22:17|"22.17 hrs"|"In Stouch it paused at the village call box to inquire whether Midwich had yet shown any signs of life. Midwich had not; it was still as deeply incommunicado as it had been since 22.17 hrs. The van restarted and rattled on through the uncertainly gathering daylight."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"
ap 10:25|ten-twenty-five|"Alan shook his head. ‘Besides
column3: ‘anything really volatile would have cleared by now. What’s more
column4: it wouldn’t have vaporized last night and caught the bus and the rest. The bus was due in Midwich at ten-twenty-five – and I came over this bit of road myself only a few minutes before that. There wasn’t anything wrong with it then. In fact
column5: that must be the bus I met just running into Oppley.’"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: 12:00|noon|"The place was quite unusually full for noon
column2: and almost entirely of strangers. The majority of them were talking somewhat histrionically in small groups or pairs; though a few individuals were drinking privately and thoughtfully. I wormed my way to the counter with some difficulty
column3: and as I was worming it back again
column5: a voice at my shoulder said:"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: 16:30|16.30|"Quite an assortment of people kept on turning up in the course of the next hour or two
column2: all apparently representing the interests of various departments
column3: civil and military. A larger tent was erected beside the Oppley road
column4: and in it a conference was called for 16.30. Colonel Latcher led off with a review of the situation. It did not take long. Just as he was concluding it a Group Captain arrived. He marched in with a malevolent air
column5: and slapped a large photograph down on to the table in front of the Colonel."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 07:00|seven|"‘Right. You can lower away now
column2: and we’ll make the trial crossing at seven.’"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 01:00|one|"‘Have you noticed
column3: dropping in one evening at Mr Crimm’s cottage
column4: ‘have you noticed the way they glare at one? Rather as if one had been currying favour with the Creator in order to be given the other sex. Quite unnerving at times. Is it the same at The Grange?’"|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 01:00|one|"‘But all the mothers
column5: exert a form of compulsion. Those who were away didn’t want to come back here; they came because they had to. I’ve talked to all of them
column6: and what they all say is that they suddenly became aware of a feeling of distress – a sense of need which they somehow knew could only be relieved by coming back here. Their attempts to describe it vary because it seems to have affected them in different ways – one felt stifled
column7: another said it was like hunger or thirst
column9: that it was like having a great noise battering at one. Ferrelyn says she simply suffered from intolerable jitters. But
column11: they felt it was associated with the babies
column12: and that the only way to relieve it was to bring them back here."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"

column1: ap 06:30|"half past six"|"At half past six we started loading his gear into the car. There seemed to be a great deal of it. Numerous cases containing projector
column6: a tape-recorder so that his words should not be lost
column7: all of them very heavy. By the time we had the lot in
column8: and a stand microphone on top
column9: it began to look as if he were starting on a lengthy safari rather than an evening’s talk."|"The Midwich Cuckoos"|"John Wyndham"
